trans-unit.source: Planning your VM backup infrastructure in Azure | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Planning your VM backup infrastructure in Azure | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Important considerations when planning to back up virtual machines in Azure
trans-unit.target: Important considerations when planning to back up virtual machines in Azure

trans-unit.source: Plan your VM backup infrastructure in Azure
trans-unit.target: Plan your VM backup infrastructure in Azure

trans-unit.source: This article covers the key things to keep in mind when planning to back up virtual machines in Azure.
trans-unit.target: This article covers the key things to keep in mind when planning to back up virtual machines in Azure.

trans-unit.source: If you've [prepared your environment](backup-azure-vms-prepare.md), this is the next step before you begin [to backup VMs](backup-azure-vms.md).
trans-unit.target: If you've [prepared your environment](backup-azure-vms-prepare.md), this is the next step before you begin [to backup VMs](backup-azure-vms.md).

trans-unit.source: If you need more information about Azure virtual machines, see the [Virtual Machines documentation](https://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/services/virtual-machines/).
trans-unit.target: If you need more information about Azure virtual machines, see the [Virtual Machines documentation](https://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/services/virtual-machines/).

trans-unit.source: How does Azure back up virtual machines?
trans-unit.target: How does Azure back up virtual machines?

trans-unit.source: When the Azure Backup service initiates a backup job at the scheduled time, it triggers the backup extension to take a point-in-time snapshot.
trans-unit.target: When the Azure Backup service initiates a backup job at the scheduled time, it triggers the backup extension to take a point-in-time snapshot.

trans-unit.source: This snapshot is taken in coordination with the Volume Shadow Copy Service (VSS) to get a consistent snapshot of the disks in the virtual machine without having to shut it down.
trans-unit.target: This snapshot is taken in coordination with the Volume Shadow Copy Service (VSS) to get a consistent snapshot of the disks in the virtual machine without having to shut it down.

trans-unit.source: After the snapshot is taken, the data is transferred by the Azure Backup service to the backup vault.
trans-unit.target: After the snapshot is taken, the data is transferred by the Azure Backup service to the backup vault.

trans-unit.source: To make the backup process more efficient, the service identifies and transfers only the blocks of data that have changed since the last backup.
trans-unit.target: To make the backup process more efficient, the service identifies and transfers only the blocks of data that have changed since the last backup.

trans-unit.source: Azure virtual machine backup architecture
trans-unit.target: Azure virtual machine backup architecture

trans-unit.source: When the data transfer is complete, the snapshot is removed and a recovery point is created.
trans-unit.target: When the data transfer is complete, the snapshot is removed and a recovery point is created.

trans-unit.source: Data consistency
trans-unit.target: Data consistency

trans-unit.source: Backing up and restoring business critical data is complicated by the fact that it needs to be backed up while the applications that produce the data are running.
trans-unit.target: Backing up and restoring business critical data is complicated by the fact that it needs to be backed up while the applications that produce the data are running.

trans-unit.source: To address this, Azure Backup provides application-consistent backups for Microsoft workloads by using VSS to ensure that data is written correctly to storage.
trans-unit.target: To address this, Azure Backup provides application-consistent backups for Microsoft workloads by using VSS to ensure that data is written correctly to storage.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] For Linux virtual machines, only file-consistent backups are possible, since Linux does not have an equivalent platform to VSS.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] For Linux virtual machines, only file-consistent backups are possible, since Linux does not have an equivalent platform to VSS.

trans-unit.source: Azure Backup takes VSS full backups on Windows VMs (read more about [VSS full backup](http://blogs.technet.com/b/filecab/archive/2008/05/21/what-is-the-difference-between-vss-full-backup-and-vss-copy-backup-in-windows-server-2008.aspx)).
trans-unit.target: Azure Backup takes VSS full backups on Windows VMs (read more about [VSS full backup](http://blogs.technet.com/b/filecab/archive/2008/05/21/what-is-the-difference-between-vss-full-backup-and-vss-copy-backup-in-windows-server-2008.aspx)).

trans-unit.source: To enable VSS copy backups, the below registry key needs to be set on the VM.
trans-unit.target: To enable VSS copy backups, the below registry key needs to be set on the VM.

trans-unit.source: This table explains the types of consistency and the conditions that they occur under during Azure VM backup and restore procedures.
trans-unit.target: This table explains the types of consistency and the conditions that they occur under during Azure VM backup and restore procedures.

trans-unit.source: Consistency
trans-unit.target: Consistency

trans-unit.source: VSS-based
trans-unit.target: VSS-based

trans-unit.source: Explanation and details
trans-unit.target: Explanation and details

trans-unit.source: Application consistency
trans-unit.target: Application consistency

trans-unit.source: Yes
trans-unit.target: Yes

trans-unit.source: This is the ideal consistency type for Microsoft workloads as it ensures that:
trans-unit.target: This is the ideal consistency type for Microsoft workloads as it ensures that:

trans-unit.source: The VM *boots up*.
trans-unit.target: The VM *boots up*.

trans-unit.source: There is *no corruption*.
trans-unit.target: There is *no corruption*.

trans-unit.source: There is *no data loss*.
trans-unit.target: There is *no data loss*.

trans-unit.source: The data is consistent to the application that uses the data, by involving the application at the time of backup--using VSS.
trans-unit.target: The data is consistent to the application that uses the data, by involving the application at the time of backup--using VSS.

trans-unit.source: Most Microsoft workloads have VSS writers that do workload-specific actions that are related to data consistency.
trans-unit.target: Most Microsoft workloads have VSS writers that do workload-specific actions that are related to data consistency.

trans-unit.source: For example, Microsoft SQL Server has a VSS writer that ensures that the writes to the transaction log file and the database are done correctly.
trans-unit.target: For example, Microsoft SQL Server has a VSS writer that ensures that the writes to the transaction log file and the database are done correctly.

trans-unit.source: For Azure VM backups, getting an application-consistent recovery point means that the backup extension was able to invoke the VSS workflow and complete it *correctly* before the VM snapshot was taken.
trans-unit.target: For Azure VM backups, getting an application-consistent recovery point means that the backup extension was able to invoke the VSS workflow and complete it *correctly* before the VM snapshot was taken.

trans-unit.source: Naturally, this means that the VSS writers of all the applications in the Azure VM have been invoked as well.
trans-unit.target: Naturally, this means that the VSS writers of all the applications in the Azure VM have been invoked as well.

trans-unit.source: (Learn the [basics of VSS](http://blogs.technet.com/b/josebda/archive/2007/10/10/the-basics-of-the-volume-shadow-copy-service-vss.aspx) and dive deep into the details of [how it works](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/cc785914%28v=ws.10%29.aspx)).
trans-unit.target: (Learn the [basics of VSS](http://blogs.technet.com/b/josebda/archive/2007/10/10/the-basics-of-the-volume-shadow-copy-service-vss.aspx) and dive deep into the details of [how it works](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/cc785914%28v=ws.10%29.aspx)).

trans-unit.source: File-system consistency
trans-unit.target: File-system consistency

trans-unit.source: Yes - for Windows-based computers
trans-unit.target: Yes - for Windows-based computers

trans-unit.source: There are two scenarios where the recovery point can be *file-system consistent*:
trans-unit.target: There are two scenarios where the recovery point can be *file-system consistent*:

trans-unit.source: Backups of Linux VMs in Azure, since Linux does not have an equivalent platform to VSS.
trans-unit.target: Backups of Linux VMs in Azure, since Linux does not have an equivalent platform to VSS.

trans-unit.source: VSS failure during backup for Windows VMs in Azure.
trans-unit.target: VSS failure during backup for Windows VMs in Azure.

trans-unit.source: In both these cases, the best that can be done is to ensure that:
trans-unit.target: In both these cases, the best that can be done is to ensure that:

trans-unit.source: The VM *boots up*.
trans-unit.target: The VM *boots up*.

trans-unit.source: There is *no corruption*.
trans-unit.target: There is *no corruption*.

trans-unit.source: There is *no data loss*.
trans-unit.target: There is *no data loss*.

trans-unit.source: Applications need to implement their own "fix-up" mechanism on the restored data.
trans-unit.target: Applications need to implement their own "fix-up" mechanism on the restored data.

trans-unit.source: Crash consistency
trans-unit.target: Crash consistency

trans-unit.source: No
trans-unit.target: No

trans-unit.source: This situation is equivalent to a virtual machine experiencing a "crash" (through either a soft or hard reset).
trans-unit.target: This situation is equivalent to a virtual machine experiencing a "crash" (through either a soft or hard reset).

trans-unit.source: This typically happens when the Azure virtual machine is shut down at the time of backup.
trans-unit.target: This typically happens when the Azure virtual machine is shut down at the time of backup.

trans-unit.source: For Azure virtual machine backups, getting a crash-consistent recovery point means that Azure Backup gives no guarantees around the consistency of the data on the storage medium--either from the perspective of the operating system or from the perspective of the application.
trans-unit.target: For Azure virtual machine backups, getting a crash-consistent recovery point means that Azure Backup gives no guarantees around the consistency of the data on the storage medium--either from the perspective of the operating system or from the perspective of the application.

trans-unit.source: Only data that already exists on the disk at the time of backup is what gets captured and backed up.
trans-unit.target: Only data that already exists on the disk at the time of backup is what gets captured and backed up.

trans-unit.source: While there are no guarantees, in most cases, the operating system will boot.
trans-unit.target: While there are no guarantees, in most cases, the operating system will boot.

trans-unit.source: This is typically followed by a disk-checking procedure, like chkdsk, to fix any corruption errors.
trans-unit.target: This is typically followed by a disk-checking procedure, like chkdsk, to fix any corruption errors.

trans-unit.source: Any in-memory data or writes that have not been completely flushed to the disk will be lost.
trans-unit.target: Any in-memory data or writes that have not been completely flushed to the disk will be lost.

trans-unit.source: The application typically follows with its own verification mechanism in case data rollback needs to be done.
trans-unit.target: The application typically follows with its own verification mechanism in case data rollback needs to be done.

trans-unit.source: As an example, if the transaction log has entries that are not present in the database, then the database software does a rollback until the data is consistent.
trans-unit.target: As an example, if the transaction log has entries that are not present in the database, then the database software does a rollback until the data is consistent.

trans-unit.source: When data is spread across multiple virtual disks (like spanned volumes), a crash-consistent recovery point provides no guarantees for the correctness of the data.
trans-unit.target: When data is spread across multiple virtual disks (like spanned volumes), a crash-consistent recovery point provides no guarantees for the correctness of the data.

trans-unit.source: Performance and resource utilization
trans-unit.target: Performance and resource utilization

trans-unit.source: Like backup software that is deployed on-premises, backing up VMs in Azure also needs to be planned for capacity and resource utilization.
trans-unit.target: Like backup software that is deployed on-premises, backing up VMs in Azure also needs to be planned for capacity and resource utilization.

trans-unit.source: The [Azure Storage limits](azure-subscription-service-limits.md#storage-limits) define how to structure VM deployments to get maximum performance with minimum impact to running workloads.
trans-unit.target: The [Azure Storage limits](azure-subscription-service-limits.md#storage-limits) define how to structure VM deployments to get maximum performance with minimum impact to running workloads.

trans-unit.source: There are two main Azure Storage limits that impact backup performance:
trans-unit.target: There are two main Azure Storage limits that impact backup performance:

trans-unit.source: Max egress per storage account
trans-unit.target: Max egress per storage account

trans-unit.source: Total request rate per storage account
trans-unit.target: Total request rate per storage account

trans-unit.source: Storage account limits
trans-unit.target: Storage account limits

trans-unit.source: When the backup data is copied out of the customer storage account, it counts towards the input/output operations per second (IOPS) and egress (storage throughput) metrics of the storage account.
trans-unit.target: When the backup data is copied out of the customer storage account, it counts towards the input/output operations per second (IOPS) and egress (storage throughput) metrics of the storage account.

trans-unit.source: At the same time, the virtual machines are running and consuming (IOPS) and throughput.
trans-unit.target: At the same time, the virtual machines are running and consuming (IOPS) and throughput.

trans-unit.source: The goal is to ensure that the total traffic--backup and virtual machine--does not exceed the storage account limits.
trans-unit.target: The goal is to ensure that the total traffic--backup and virtual machine--does not exceed the storage account limits.

trans-unit.source: Number of disks
trans-unit.target: Number of disks

trans-unit.source: The backup process is greedy and tries to consume as many resources as it can, with the aim of completing backup as quickly as possible.
trans-unit.target: The backup process is greedy and tries to consume as many resources as it can, with the aim of completing backup as quickly as possible.

trans-unit.source: However, all I/O operations are limited by the *Target Throughput for Single Blob*, which has a limit of 60 MB per second.
trans-unit.target: However, all I/O operations are limited by the *Target Throughput for Single Blob*, which has a limit of 60 MB per second.

trans-unit.source: In order to speed up the backup process, the backup of each disk of the VM is attempted *in parallel*.
trans-unit.target: In order to speed up the backup process, the backup of each disk of the VM is attempted *in parallel*.

trans-unit.source: So, if a VM has four disks, then Azure Backup will attempt to back up all four disks in parallel.
trans-unit.target: So, if a VM has four disks, then Azure Backup will attempt to back up all four disks in parallel.

trans-unit.source: Because of this, the single most important factor that determines the backup traffic exiting from a customer storage account is the **number of disks** being backed up from the storage account.
trans-unit.target: Because of this, the single most important factor that determines the backup traffic exiting from a customer storage account is the **number of disks** being backed up from the storage account.

trans-unit.source: Backup schedule
trans-unit.target: Backup schedule

trans-unit.source: An additional factor that impacts performance is the **backup schedule**.
trans-unit.target: An additional factor that impacts performance is the **backup schedule**.

trans-unit.source: If you configure all the VMs to back up at the same time, then the number of disks being backed up *in parallel* will increase--as Azure Backup will attempt to back up as many disks as possible.
trans-unit.target: If you configure all the VMs to back up at the same time, then the number of disks being backed up *in parallel* will increase--as Azure Backup will attempt to back up as many disks as possible.

trans-unit.source: So one way to reduce the backup traffic from a storage account is to ensure that different VMs are backed up at different times of the day, with no overlap.
trans-unit.target: So one way to reduce the backup traffic from a storage account is to ensure that different VMs are backed up at different times of the day, with no overlap.

trans-unit.source: Capacity planning
trans-unit.target: Capacity planning

trans-unit.source: Putting all these factors together means that storage account usage needs to be planned properly.
trans-unit.target: Putting all these factors together means that storage account usage needs to be planned properly.

trans-unit.source: Download the [VM backup capacity planning Excel spreadsheet](https://gallery.technet.microsoft.com/Azure-Backup-Storage-a46d7e33) to see the impact of your disk and backup schedule choices.
trans-unit.target: Download the [VM backup capacity planning Excel spreadsheet](https://gallery.technet.microsoft.com/Azure-Backup-Storage-a46d7e33) to see the impact of your disk and backup schedule choices.

trans-unit.source: Backup throughput
trans-unit.target: Backup throughput

trans-unit.source: For each disk being backed up, Azure Backup reads the blocks on the disk and stores only the changed data (incremental backup).
trans-unit.target: For each disk being backed up, Azure Backup reads the blocks on the disk and stores only the changed data (incremental backup).

trans-unit.source: This table shows the average throughput values that you can expect from Azure Backup.
trans-unit.target: This table shows the average throughput values that you can expect from Azure Backup.

trans-unit.source: Using this, you can estimate the amount of time that it will take to back up a disk of a given size.
trans-unit.target: Using this, you can estimate the amount of time that it will take to back up a disk of a given size.

trans-unit.source: Backup operation
trans-unit.target: Backup operation

trans-unit.source: Best-case throughput
trans-unit.target: Best-case throughput

trans-unit.source: Initial backup
trans-unit.target: Initial backup

trans-unit.source: 160 Mbps
trans-unit.target: 160 Mbps

trans-unit.source: Incremental backup (DR)
trans-unit.target: Incremental backup (DR)

trans-unit.source: 640 Mbps
trans-unit.target: 640 Mbps

trans-unit.source: This throughput can drop significantly if there is a lot of dispersed churn on the disk that needs to be backed up.
trans-unit.target: This throughput can drop significantly if there is a lot of dispersed churn on the disk that needs to be backed up.

trans-unit.source: Total VM backup time
trans-unit.target: Total VM backup time

trans-unit.source: While a majority of the backup time is spent in reading and copying data, there are other operations that contribute to the total time needed to back up a VM:
trans-unit.target: While a majority of the backup time is spent in reading and copying data, there are other operations that contribute to the total time needed to back up a VM:

trans-unit.source: Time needed to [install or update the backup extension](backup-azure-vms.md#offline-vms).
trans-unit.target: Time needed to [install or update the backup extension](backup-azure-vms.md#offline-vms).

trans-unit.source: Snapshot time, which is the time taken to trigger a snapshot.
trans-unit.target: Snapshot time, which is the time taken to trigger a snapshot.

trans-unit.source: Snapshots are triggered close to the scheduled backup time.
trans-unit.target: Snapshots are triggered close to the scheduled backup time.

trans-unit.source: Queue wait time.
trans-unit.target: Queue wait time.

trans-unit.source: Since the Backup service is processing backups from multiple customers, copying backup data from snapshot to the Azure backup vault might not start immediately.
trans-unit.target: Since the Backup service is processing backups from multiple customers, copying backup data from snapshot to the Azure backup vault might not start immediately.

trans-unit.source: In times of peak load, the wait times can stretch up to 8 hours due to the number of backups being processed.
trans-unit.target: In times of peak load, the wait times can stretch up to 8 hours due to the number of backups being processed.

trans-unit.source: However, the total VM backup time will be less than 24 hours for daily backup policies.
trans-unit.target: However, the total VM backup time will be less than 24 hours for daily backup policies.

trans-unit.source: Data encryption
trans-unit.target: Data encryption

trans-unit.source: Azure Backup does not encrypt data as a part of the backup process.
trans-unit.target: Azure Backup does not encrypt data as a part of the backup process.

trans-unit.source: However, you can encrypt data within the VM and back up the protected data seamlessly (read more about [backup of encrypted data](backup-azure-vms-encryption.md)).
trans-unit.target: However, you can encrypt data within the VM and back up the protected data seamlessly (read more about [backup of encrypted data](backup-azure-vms-encryption.md)).

trans-unit.source: How are protected instances calculated?
trans-unit.target: How are protected instances calculated?

trans-unit.source: Azure virtual machines that are backed up through Azure Backup are subject to [Azure Backup pricing](https://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/details/backup/).
trans-unit.target: Azure virtual machines that are backed up through Azure Backup are subject to [Azure Backup pricing](https://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/details/backup/).

trans-unit.source: The Protected Instances calculation is based on the *actual* size of the virtual machine, which is the sum of all the data in the virtual machine--excluding the “resource disk”.
trans-unit.target: The Protected Instances calculation is based on the *actual* size of the virtual machine, which is the sum of all the data in the virtual machine--excluding the “resource disk”.

trans-unit.source: You are *not* billed based on the maximum size that is supported for each data disk attached to the virtual machine, but on the actual data stored in the data disk.
trans-unit.target: You are *not* billed based on the maximum size that is supported for each data disk attached to the virtual machine, but on the actual data stored in the data disk.

trans-unit.source: Similarly, the backup storage bill is based on the amount of data that is stored with Azure Backup, which is the sum of the actual data in each recovery point.
trans-unit.target: Similarly, the backup storage bill is based on the amount of data that is stored with Azure Backup, which is the sum of the actual data in each recovery point.

trans-unit.source: For example, take an A2 Standard-sized virtual machine that has two additional data disks with a maximum size of 1 TB each.
trans-unit.target: For example, take an A2 Standard-sized virtual machine that has two additional data disks with a maximum size of 1 TB each.

trans-unit.source: The table below gives the actual data stored on each of these disks:
trans-unit.target: The table below gives the actual data stored on each of these disks:

trans-unit.source: Disk type
trans-unit.target: Disk type

trans-unit.source: Max size
trans-unit.target: Max size

trans-unit.source: Actual data present
trans-unit.target: Actual data present

trans-unit.source: Operating system disk
trans-unit.target: Operating system disk

trans-unit.source: 17 GB
trans-unit.target: 17 GB

trans-unit.source: Local disk / Resource disk
trans-unit.target: Local disk / Resource disk

trans-unit.source: 135 GB
trans-unit.target: 135 GB

trans-unit.source: 5 GB (not included for backup)
trans-unit.target: 5 GB (not included for backup)

trans-unit.source: Data disk 1
trans-unit.target: Data disk 1

trans-unit.source: 30 GB
trans-unit.target: 30 GB

trans-unit.source: Data disk 2
trans-unit.target: Data disk 2

trans-unit.source: 0 GB
trans-unit.target: 0 GB

trans-unit.source: The *actual* size of the virtual machine in this case is 17 GB + 30 GB + 0 GB = 47 GB.
trans-unit.target: The *actual* size of the virtual machine in this case is 17 GB + 30 GB + 0 GB = 47 GB.

trans-unit.source: This becomes the Protected Instance size that the monthly bill is based on.
trans-unit.target: This becomes the Protected Instance size that the monthly bill is based on.

trans-unit.source: As the amount of data in the virtual machine grows, the Protected Instance size used for billing also will change accordingly.
trans-unit.target: As the amount of data in the virtual machine grows, the Protected Instance size used for billing also will change accordingly.

trans-unit.source: Billing does not start until the first successful backup is completed.
trans-unit.target: Billing does not start until the first successful backup is completed.

trans-unit.source: At this point, the billing for both Storage and Protected Instances will begin.
trans-unit.target: At this point, the billing for both Storage and Protected Instances will begin.

trans-unit.source: Billing continues as long as there is *any backup data stored with Azure Backup* for the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: Billing continues as long as there is *any backup data stored with Azure Backup* for the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Performing the Stop Protection operation does not stop the billing if the backup data is retained.
trans-unit.target: Performing the Stop Protection operation does not stop the billing if the backup data is retained.

trans-unit.source: The billing for a specified virtual machine will be discontinued only if the protection is stopped *and* any backup data is deleted.
trans-unit.target: The billing for a specified virtual machine will be discontinued only if the protection is stopped *and* any backup data is deleted.

trans-unit.source: When there are no active backup jobs (when protection has been stopped), the size of the virtual machine at the time of the last successful backup becomes the Protected Instance size that the monthly bill is based on.
trans-unit.target: When there are no active backup jobs (when protection has been stopped), the size of the virtual machine at the time of the last successful backup becomes the Protected Instance size that the monthly bill is based on.

trans-unit.source: Questions?
trans-unit.target: Questions?

trans-unit.source: If you have questions, or if there is any feature that you would like to see included, [send us feedback](http://aka.ms/azurebackup_feedback).
trans-unit.target: If you have questions, or if there is any feature that you would like to see included, [send us feedback](http://aka.ms/azurebackup_feedback).
